We have not sent down to you the Qur'an that you be distressed
But only as a reminder for those who fear [Allah] -
A revelation from He who created the earth and highest heavens,
The Most Merciful [who is] above the Throne established.
To Him belongs what is in the heavens and what is on the earth and what is between them and what is under the soil.
And if you speak aloud - then indeed, He knows the secret and what is [even] more hidden.
Allah - there is no deity except Him. To Him belong the best names.
And has the story of Moses reached you? -
When he saw a fire and said to his family, "Stay here; indeed, I have perceived a fire; perhaps I can bring you a torch or find at the fire some guidance."
And when he came to it, he was called, "O Moses,
Indeed, I am your Lord, so remove your sandals. Indeed, you are in the sacred valley of Tuwa.

Indeed, the apparent command necessitates obligation, and heedlessness [ghafla] opposes remembrance [dhikr]. So how can one who is heedless throughout all of his prayer be establishing the prayer for My remembrance? (The Virtue of Humility [khushu']) "Indeed, I am Allah. There is no deity except Me, so worship Me and establish prayer for My remembrance." (20:14) And He, the Exalted, said: "And do not be among the heedless [ghafilin]." (7:205) And He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "Do not approach prayer while you are intoxicated [sukara] until you know what you are saying." (4:43) It is said: 'intoxicated from the multitude of concerns,' and it is said: 'from the love of the world [dunya].' And Wahb said: 'What is intended is its apparent meaning.' So in it is an alert to the intoxication of the world [dunya], for He stated the reason within it, saying: "until you know what you are saying." (4:43) And how many a person praying [musalli] has not drunk wine, yet he does not know what he is saying in his prayer! And the Prophet, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever prays two units [rak'atayn] without conversing with himself therein about anything of the world [dunya], his preceding sins are forgiven for him." And he, peace be upon him, said: "Verily, prayer [salah] is restraint, humility, supplication, sighing, remorse, and placing your hands [in supplication] while you say: 'O Allah, O Allah.' So whoever does not do that, then it is deficient." And it is narrated from Allah, glorified is He, in the previous scriptures that He said: 'I do not accept the prayer [salah] of every person praying [musalli]. I only accept the prayer [salah] of one who humbles himself before My majesty, does not act arrogantly over My servants, and feeds the hungry poor for the sake of My Face.' And he, peace be upon him, said: "Prayer [salah] was only prescribed, and the Hajj, circumambulation [tawaf], and the rites [manasik] were commanded, for the establishment of the remembrance [dhikr] of Allah, the Exalted. So if there is not in your heart [qalb] for the One Remembered [madhkur], who is the intended goal and objective, any majesty or awe, then what is the value of your remembrance [dhikr]?" And he, peace be upon him, said to the one he advised: "And when you pray, pray the prayer [salah] of one bidding farewell." Meaning, bidding farewell to his soul [nafs], bidding farewell to his desire [hawa], bidding farewell to his lifespan, journeying to his Master, as He, the Mighty and Majestic, said: "O mankind, indeed you are laboring toward your Lord with [great] exertion and will meet Him." (84:6) And He, the Exalted, said: "And fear Allah; and Allah teaches you." (2:282) And He, the Exalted, said: "And fear Allah and know that you will meet Him." (2:223) And he, peace be upon him, said: "Whoever is not prevented by his prayer [salah] from immorality and wrongdoing, he only increases in distance from Allah." And prayer [salah] is a confidential discourse [munajat]; so how can it be with heedlessness [ghafla]?

He said, "They are close upon my tracks, and I hastened to You, my Lord, that You be pleased."
[Allah] said, "But indeed, We have tried your people after you [departed], and the Samiri has led them astray."

So Moses returned to his people, angry and grieved. He said, "O my people, did your Lord not make you a good promise? Then, was the time [of its fulfillment] too long for you, or did you wish that wrath from your Lord descend upon you, so you broke your promise [of obedience] to me?"

They said, "We did not break our promise to you by our will, but we were made to carry burdens from the ornaments of the people [of Pharaoh], so we threw them [into the fire], and thus did the Samiri throw."
And he extracted for them [the statue of] a calf which had a lowing sound, and they said, "This is your god and the god of Moses, but he forgot."
Did they not see that it could not return to them any speech and that it did not possess for them any harm or benefit?
And Aaron had already told them before [the return of Moses], "O my people, you are only being tested by it, and indeed, your Lord is the Most Merciful, so follow me and obey my order."
They said, "We will never cease being devoted to the calf until Moses returns to us."
[Moses] said, "O Aaron, what prevented you, when you saw them going astray,
From following me? Then have you disobeyed my order?"

[Aaron] said, "O son of my mother, do not seize [me] by my beard or by my head. Indeed, I feared that you would say, 'You caused division among the Children of Israel, and you did not observe [or await] my word.' "
[Moses] said, "And what is your case, O Samiri?"
He said, "I saw what they did not see, so I took a handful [of dust] from the track of the messenger and threw it, and thus did my soul entice me."

[Moses] said, "Then go. And indeed, it is [decreed] for you in [this] life to say, 'No contact.' And indeed, you have an appointment [in the Hereafter] you will not fail to keep. And look at your 'god' to which you remained devoted. We will surely burn it and blow it into the sea with a blast.
Your god is only Allah, except for whom there is no deity. He has encompassed all things in knowledge."
Thus, [O Muhammad], We relate to you from the news of what has preceded. And We have certainly given you from Us the Qur'an.
Whoever turns away from it - then indeed, he will bear on the Day of Resurrection a burden,
[Abiding] eternally therein, and evil it is for them on the Day of Resurrection as a load -
The Day the Horn will be blown. And We will gather the criminals, that Day, blue-eyed.
They will murmur among themselves, "You remained not but ten [days in the world]."
We are most knowing of what they say when the best of them in manner will say, "You remained not but one day."
And they ask you about the mountains, so say, "My Lord will blow them away with a blast.
And He will leave the earth a level plain;
You will not see therein a depression or an elevation."
That Day, everyone will follow [the call of] the Caller [with] no deviation therefrom, and [all] voices will be stilled before the Most Merciful, so you will not hear except a whisper [of footsteps].
That Day, no intercession will benefit except [that of] one to whom the Most Merciful has given permission and has accepted his word.

Indeed, as He, the Almighty, has said: **"Thus did Our signs come to you, and you forgot them; and thus today you are forgotten."** That is, you abandoned them and did not look upon them, nor did you pay them any heed, for the one who is negligent in a matter is said to have forgotten the matter. And the true recitation [tilawa] of the Qur'an is that the tongue [lisan], the intellect ['aql], and the heart [qalb] all partake in it. The portion of the tongue is the correct pronunciation of the letters with measured recitation [tartil]; the portion of the intellect is the interpretation of the meanings; and the portion of the heart is to take admonition [i'tizaz] and to be affected by the warning and the command. He said: So the Messenger of God, peace and blessings of God the Exalted be upon him, turned away from them and lowered his gaze. So it was said to him: "O Messenger of God, these are the most precious of our possessions, why do you not look at them?" He said: "God has indeed forbidden me from that." Then he recited His Exalted's saying: "And do not extend your eyes toward that by which We have given enjoyment..." the verse. And from Abu Rafi' that he said: A guest came to the Messenger of God, peace and blessings of God be upon him, and he did not find with him what would be suitable for him. So he sent me to a man from the Jews of Khaybar and said: "Say to him: Muhammad says to you: Lend me or sell me some flour until the crescent of Rajab." He said: So I came to him and he said: "No, by God, except with a pledge." And when I went out, this verse was revealed: "And do not extend your eyes toward that by which We have given enjoyment to groups of them, as the glitter of the life of the world [zahrat al-hayat al-dunya]..." the verse.
